abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Lessons point primarily at
            the importance of the Government's active program of
            privatization, and regulatory development, which ran in
            parallel with the investments financed by the project,
            allowing maximum benefits deriving from the liberalized
            energy markets, both Hungarian, and European. However, the
            reluctance of the Government to expose Hungarian consumers
            to the full costs of electricity supply - though
            understandable, but a factor rather to be placed in the
            context of anti-inflation and other policy considerations -
            constraints the ability of the Hungarian Power Company, to
            confidently plan sector needs, weakening the company's
            creditworthiness. Thus, the issue of independent energy
            regulation and economic pricing, remain indicators to
            monitor, and evaluate, well after restructuring, and
            privatization. Nevertheless, the highly professional, and
            motivated management provided by the power company, was a
            crucial ingredient for success, which underlines the
            importance of ensuring institutional, and management arrangements.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy and Environment Project will
            support Hungary's reform program by mitigating the
            country's dependence on energy imports from a single
            source; by increasing efficiency, reliability and
            flexibility in the production of electricity and heat; and
            by establishing the necessary basis for strong
            interconnections with the Western European Power Pool. In
            addition, the project will support continued environmental
            improvements in the power sector, and assist in improving
            institutional capabilities. The project will consist of the
            following components: (i) construction of the gas-fired
            combined cycle co-generation unit of 235 MWe and 240 MWt at
            the Dunamenti Power Plant site about 30 km southwest of
            Budapest; (ii) upgrade of Hungarian Power Companies Ltd.
            (MVM Rt's) existing Energy Management System (EMS);
            (iii) assistance to: (a) develop an Environmental Master
            Plan, (b) reinforce the environmental management and
            monitoring capabilities of MVM Rt; and (c) install water
            pollution, ambient air and noise level monitoring equipment
            at selected sites; and (iv) assistance to upgrade the human
            resource management, training and institution-building
            capacity in the power sector.

734713.trustfund:
TF026081-USTDA CTF,TF026080-USTDP ENVIRONMENTAL

repnme.cdata!:
Hungary - Energy environment project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The study discusses the following
            topics: 1) assessment of impact factors, potential impact
            procedures and impact receptors; 2) preliminary estimation
            of affected area, information on the environmental
            conditions of the affected area; 3) selection of the
            relevant impact procedures; 4) brief evaluation; and 5)
            proposed way to proceed with further investigation.  Issues
            addressed by the study are: 1) what types of the
            environmental impacts can be expected? 2) to what degree is
            the impact expected to exert itself? 3) when is it due to
            occur and how long will it last? 4) who or what will be
            affected? and 5) will it endanger or keep the environmental
            control limits?  This study describes the purpose of the
            project and summarizes the expected results.  It analyses
            the possible alternatives and arrives at the conclusion that
            the implementation of the long-term development of the
            electric power system proved to be the most advantageous.

docna.cdata!:
Hungary - Energy environment project :
            environmental assessment
